question: You didn't wake me.
answer: You were sleeping.

question: You let me sleep because you can't bear to have breakfast with me.
answer: Nothing could be further from the truth. I boiled you an egg. See? I'd hardly have boiled you an egg if I didn't want to see you. Tea or coffee?

question: Does any woman ever stay long enough to find out what the hell goes on in your head? What are you doing tonight?
answer: I'm seeing my daughter.

question: Your daughter? You've kept very quiet about her.
answer: Have I? She's been abroad for a year. Did you say tea?

question: Hey. Hey! Hey, kid. Hey.
answer: I'm sorry. I'm sorry.

question: Where do you live?
answer: It's here. I'll be fine now. Thank you.

question: Michael's fifteen. Keep away. He's contagious. How are you feeling?
answer: Better. By the way, I meant to tell you, the day I got ill... a woman helped me. A woman in the street.

question: She helped you?
answer: Yes. She brought me home.

question: I brought you these flowers. To say thank you.
answer: Put them down there.

question: I would have come earlier, but I've been in bed for three months.
answer: You're better now?

question: Thank you.
answer: Have you always been weak?

question: Oh no. I'd never been ill before. It's incredibly boring. There's nothing to do. I couldn't even be bothered to read.
answer: I have to go to work. I'll walk with you. Wait in the hall while I change. There are two more buckets downstairs. You can fill them and bring them up.

question: It's hardly my fault, I got lost, that's all. That's why I was late. Can I have some more?
answer: How can anyone get lost in their own home town?

question: The doctor told me I had to take walks.
answer: So?

question: I meant to head for the castle, I ended up at the sports-field.
answer: They're in opposite directions.

question: It's none of your business.
answer: He's lying.

question: He's not lying. Michael never lies.
answer: Dad, I've decided, I want to go back to school tomorrow.

question: The doctor says you need another three weeks.
answer: Well I'm going.

question: What's your name?
answer: What?

question: Your name.
answer: Why do you want to know?

question: I've been here three times. You haven't told me your name.
answer: It's Hanna. What's yours, kid?

question: Michael.
answer: Michael. Hmm. So I'm with a Michael.

question: `Hanna'.
answer: You never tell me what you've been studying.

question: Studying?
answer: At school. Do you learn languages?

question: Yes.
answer: What languages?

question: Latin.
answer: Say something in Latin.

question: Oh... Quo, quo scelesti ruitis? Aut cur dexteris aptantur enses conditi? It's Horace.
answer: It's wonderful.

question: Do you want some Greek? Oi men ippeon stroton oi de pesedon oi da naon phais epi gan malainan emmenai kalliston, ego de ken otto tis eratai.
answer: It's beautiful.

question: How can you tell? How do you know when you've no idea what it means?
answer: What about in German?

question: In German?
answer: Do you have anything?

question: Well, I'm writing an essay. It's about a play. By a writer called Gotthold Ephraim Lessing. Perhaps you've heard of him? The play's called Emilia Galotti.
answer: Have you got it?

question: Here. You can read it.
answer: I'd rather listen to you.

question: All right. I'm not very good. Act One. Scene One. The setting
answer: You're good at it, aren't you?

question: Good at what?
answer: Reading. Why are you smiling?

question: I got up - at 4.30 - specially - it's the first day of the holidays, I'd been planning to surprise you -
answer: Poor little baby. Got up at four thirty - and on your holidays too.

question: What is this? I was on your tram! You totally ignored me! What do you think I was doing? Why the hell do you think I was there?
answer: I haven't the slightest idea. And what you do is your business not mine. And if you wanted to speak to me, I was in the first carriage. So why did you sit in the second? And now, thanks very much, I've been working, I need a bath. Get out, I'd like to be by myself.

question: I didn't mean to upset you.
answer: You don't have the power to upset me. You don't matter enough to upset me.

question: I don't know what to say. I've never been with a woman. We've been together four weeks and I can't live without you. I can't. Even the thought of it kills me. I sat in the second carriage because I thought you might kiss me.
answer: Kid, you thought we could make love in a tram?

question: Is it true what you said? That I don't matter to you? Do you forgive me? Do you love me?
answer: Do you have a book?

question: Oh. Well I do. I took something with me this morning.
answer: What is it?

question: It's another play.
answer: We're changing the order we do things. Read to me first, kid. Then we make love.

question: The Odyssey by Homer.
answer: What's an odyssey?

question: It's a journey. He sets out on a journey. "Sing to me of the Man, Muse, the man of twists and turns Driven time and again off course, once he had plundered The hallowed heights of Troy. Many cities of men he saw and learned their minds, Many pains he suffered, heartsick at the open sea, Fighting to save his life and bring his comrades home... "And we will some new pleasures prove of golden sands and crystal brooks, with silken lights and silver hooks..."
answer: Come here.

question: "Lady Chatterley felt his naked flesh against her as he came into her. For a moment he was still inside her...
answer: This is disgusting. Where did you get this?

question: I borrowed it from someone at school.
answer: You should be ashamed. Go on.

question: `Blistering Barnacles and a thundering typhoon. It is water.' `But what on earth did you expect it to be?'
answer: Whisky.

question: Whisky! By thunder, whisky. `Whisky? Come now captain, you can't be serious.'
answer: All right, kid, that's enough for today.

question: I was wondering, do you think you could get some time off? Maybe we could go for a trip.
answer: What sort of trip?

question: I'd love to go bicycling. Just for two days. I've got a guide-book. I've worked out the route. Look, what do you think?
answer: I think you like planning, don't you?

question: What are you having?
answer: You order. I'll have what you have.

question: Thank you. She enjoyed her meal very much. Here, let me show you where we're going.
answer: It's OK, kid. I don't want to know. What are you doing?

question: I'm writing a poem. About you.
answer: Can I hear it?

question: Oh kid, kid. Stop.
answer: What's wrong?

question: Nothing's wrong. It's nothing.
answer: You never ask, you never bother to ask how I am.

question: You never say.
answer: It just happens to be my birthday. It's my birthday, that's all. In fact, you've never even asked when it is.

question: Look if you want a fight, kid...
answer: No, I don't want a fight. What's wrong with you?

question: What business is it of yours?
answer: It's always on your terms. Everything. We do what you want. It's always what you want. My friends were giving me a party!

question: Well then why are you here? Go back to your party. Isn't that what you want?
answer: And it's always me that has to apologize.

question: Thank you.
answer: I was early.

question: Julia. Welcome back. So how will you decide?
answer: I don't know. I'm happy back in Berlin, I suppose.

question: You've seen your mother?
answer: I wanted to get away. There was nothing more to it. It was Paris, but it could have been anywhere.

question: Away from your parents? I'm aware I was difficult. I wasn't always open with you. I'm not open with anyone.
answer: I knew you were distant. I'd always assumed it was my fault.

question: Julia. How wrong can you be? I admit it now, I was nervous.
answer: I was nervous too. It's silly isn't it?

question: It is silly.
answer: Thank you for dinner.

question: I'll see you very soon.
answer: Good night, Dad.

question: Julia, wait. I want to ask you a favour.
answer: What favour?

question: I want to take you on a trip. I want to show you something.
answer: When?

question: And ladies. So this is where you are.
answer: Yes. Come in.

question: You take work seriously.
answer: Oh I don't know.

question: You're rather a serious boy.
answer: It's how I was brought up. What about you? Are you serious?

question: You're sure you want to work tonight?
answer: Well I do. But I won't work every night.

question: Hanna Schmitz. Your name is Hanna Schmitz?
answer: Yes.

question: Can you speak louder please?
answer: My name is Hanna Schmitz.

question: Thank you. You were born on October 21st, 1922?
answer: Yes.

question: At Hermannstadt. And you're now 43 years old?
answer: Yes.

question: You joined the SS in 1943?
answer: Yes.

question: What was your reason? What was your reason for joining? You were working at the Siemens factory at the time?
answer: Yes.

question: You'd recently been offered a promotion. Why did you prefer to join the SS? I'll re-phrase my question. I'm trying to ascertain if she joined the SS freely. Of her own free will. Well?
answer: I heard there were jobs.

question: Go on.
answer: I was working at Siemens when I heard the SS was recruiting.

question: Did you know the kind of work you'd be expected to do?
answer: They were looking for guards. I applied for a job.

question: And you worked first at Auschwitz?
answer: Yes.

question: Until 1944. Then you were moved to a smaller camp near Cracow?
answer: Yes.

question: Wasn't it? In what way? What were you expecting?
answer: I thought it was exciting.

question: Exciting?
answer: Yes.

question: Why? Why did you think it exciting?
answer: Because it's justice.

question: I need to correct an impression. Dieter said yesterday this was about justice. But is it?
answer: I'd have thought it was obvious.

question: Say.
answer: Cowardice. It's cowardice, isn't it? It's bad conscience. It's the big cover-up.

question: Go on.
answer: After the war. The German people didn't want to look at what they'd done.

question: Is that right?
answer: Because they had too much to hide. All our parents are liars. All right, mine are. So it's left to us, isn't it?

question: How so?
answer: Because we're not implicated.

question: Aren't you? Good. So that's all right then.
answer: No, but seriously, Dieter's right. My parents, I can't even talk to them. I don't love them. How could I? How could anyone love them? Because they've told themselves so many lies, they can't remember the truth, let alone admit it. Isn't that why we signed up for this seminar?

question: I don't know. You tell me.
answer: Speaking for myself.

question: Societies think they operate by something called morality. But they don't. They operate by something called law. You're not guilty of anything merely by working at Auschwitz. 8,000 people worked at Auschwitz. Precisely 19 have been convicted, and only 6 for murder. To prove murder you have to prove intent. That's the law. Remember, the question is never `Was it wrong?' but `Was it legal?' And not by our laws, no, by the laws at the time.
answer: But isn't that...

question: What?
answer: Narrow?

question: Miss Schmitz, you're familiar with this book...
answer: Yes...

question: Parts of it have already been read out in court.
answer: Yes I know. I know Ilana Mather.

question: She was in the camp, wasn't she, when she was a child? She was with her mother. In the book, she describes a selection process. At the end of the month's labour, every month, sixty inmates were selected. They were picked out to be sent from the satellite camp back to Auschwitz. That's right, isn't it?
answer: Yes, it's right.

question: And so far, each of your fellow defendants has specifically denied being part of that process. Now I'm going to ask you. Were you part of it?
answer: Yes.

question: So you helped make the selection?
answer: Yes.

question: You admit that? Then tell me, how did that selection happen?
answer: There were six guards, so we decided we'd choose ten people each. That's how we did it - every month. We'd all choose ten.

question: Are you saying your fellow defendants took part in the process?
answer: We all did.

question: Even though they've denied it? But you admit it. You're saying you took part in the process. Did you not realise you were sending these women to their deaths?
answer: Yes but there were new arrivals, new women were arriving all the time, so of course we had to move some of the old ones on.

question: I'm not sure you understand...
answer: We couldn't keep everyone. There wasn't room.

question: No, but what I'm saying
answer: Well, what would you have done? So should I never have signed up at Siemens?

question: I want to move on now to the march. As I understand it, you and your daughter were marched for many months.
answer: Yes. It was the winter of 1944. Our camp was closed down, we were told we had to move on. But the plan kept changing every day. Women were dying all around us in the snow. Half of us died on the march. My daughter says in the book, less a death march, more a death gallop.

question: Please tell us about the night in the church.
answer: That night we actually thought we were lucky because we had a roof over our heads. We'd arrived in a village, as always, the guards took the best quarters, they took the priest's house. But they let us sleep in a church. There was a bombing raid. In the middle of the night. At first we could only hear the fire, it was in the steeple. Then we could see burning beams, and they began to crash to the floor. Everyone rushed, rushed to the doors. But the doors had been locked on the outside.

question: The church burned down? Nobody came to open the doors? Is that right?
answer: Nobody.

question: Even though you were all burning to death? How many people were killed?
answer: Everyone was killed.

question: How did you survive?
answer: I needed to get away from the other women. Because they were panicking, they were screaming. I couldn't stand it. I couldn't stand their screaming. I was more frightened of the other women than I was of the fire. So I too my daughter and led her to the upper floor. I can't defend what I did. It's impossible to defend. I took Ilana in my arms and I led her towards the fire. There was a small gallery at the side of the church on the upper level. It saved our lives. The gallery didn't burn.

question: I don't know. I don't know what we're doing any more.
answer: Don't you?

question: You keep telling us to think like lawyers, but there's something disgusting about this.
answer: How so?

question: You choose six women, you put them on trial, you say `They were the evil ones, they were the guilty ones'. Brilliant! People go on about how much did everyone know? `Who knew?' `What did they know?' That isn't the question. The question is `How could you let it happen?' And - better - `Why didn't you kill yourself when you found out?' Thousands! That's how many. There were thousands of camps. Everyone knew. Look at that woman...
answer: Which woman?

question: The woman you're always staring at. I'm sorry but you are.
answer: I don't know which woman you mean.

question: Why did you not unlock the doors? Why did you not unlock the doors? I've asked all of you and I'm getting no answer. Two of the victims are in this court. They deserve an answer. Here, this is the SS report. You all have copies. This is the report which was written, approved and signed by all of you immediately after the event. In the written report, you all claim you didn't even know about the fire until after it happened. But that isn't true, is it? Well? It isn't true.
answer: I don't know what you're asking.

question: The first thing I'm asking is, why didn't you unlock the doors?
answer: Obviously. For the obvious reason. We couldn't.

question: Why? Why couldn't you?
answer: We were guards. Our job was to guard the prisoners. We couldn't just let them escape.

question: I see. And if they escaped, then you'd be blamed, you'd be charged, you might even be executed?
answer: No.

question: Well then?
answer: If we opened the doors, then there would have been chaos. How could we have restored order?

question: So you did know what was happening? You did know? You made a choice. You let them die rather than risk letting them escape. The other defendants have made an allegation against you. Have you heard this allegation? They say you were in charge.
answer: It isn't true. I was just one of the guards.

question: Did you write the report?
answer: No. No. We all discussed what to say. We all wrote it together.

question: Is that true?
answer: No. And I didn't write the report. Does it matter who did?

question: I need to see a sample of your handwriting.
answer: My handwriting?

question: You've been skipping seminars. So?
answer: I have a piece of information. Concerning one of the defendants. Something they're not admitting.

question: What information? You don't need me to tell you. It's perfectly clear you have a moral obligation to disclose it to the court.
answer: It happens this information is favourable to the defendant. It can help her case. It may even affect the outcome, certainly the sentencing.

question: So?
answer: There's a problem. The defendant herself is determined to keep this information secret.

question: A moment, please. Please. What are her reasons?
answer: Because she's ashamed.

question: Ashamed? Ashamed of what? Have you spoken to her?
answer: Of course not.

question: Why of course not?
answer: I can't. I can't do that. I can't talk to her.

question: You didn't come for your father's funeral, but you come for this?
answer: You know, it's not easy for me to visit this town.

question: Were you really so unhappy?
answer: That's not what I'm saying. It's not what I meant.

question: Well then?
answer: You mustn't worry about Gertrud. I'm going to look after her. And anyway, let's face it, she's already a state prosecutor, she earns far more than I do.

question: You went to the West? My God, what a trip.
answer: We went to say hello to granny.

question: Oh. Daddy took you to see Carla, did he?
answer: She was strange.

question: Come on, let's see what's on TV. I bet she was strange.
answer: You could say.

question: She always was. Why on earth did you decide to do that?
answer: I don't know. Impulse. I suppose if I'm honest we went because I wanted to re-establish contact.

question: With your mother? And did you succeed?
answer: Are you all right?

question: You got my letter?
answer: I have it here.

question: As I say, Hanna Schmitz is coming up for release very soon. Hanna has been in prison for over twenty years. She has no family. She has no friends. You're her only contact. And I'm told you don't visit her.
answer: No. I don't.

question: When she gets out, she's going to need a job. She's going to need somewhere to live. You can't imagine how frightening the modern world will seem to her.
answer: Yes. I'm still here.

question: I have no-one else to ask. If you don't take responsibility for her, then Hanna has no future at all.
answer: It's kind of you. Thank you for letting me know.

question: You're Michael Berg?
answer: Yes.

question: You've grown up, kid.
answer: I've got a friend who's a tailor, he makes my suits. He'll give you a job. And I've found you somewhere to live. It's a nice place. Quite small but nice. I think you'll like it.

question: Thank you.
answer: There are various social programmes, cultural stuff I can sign you up for. And there's a public library very close. You read a lot?

question: I prefer being read to. That's over now, isn't it? Did you get married?
answer: I did. Yes I did. We have a daughter. I'm not seeing as much of her as I would like. I'd like to see a great deal more of her. The marriage didn't last. Have you spent a lot of time thinking about the past?

question: You mean, with you?
answer: No. No, I didn't mean with me.

question: Before the trial I never thought about the past. I never had to.
answer: And now? What do you feel now?

question: It doesn't matter what I think. It doesn't matter what I feel. The dead are still dead.
answer: I wasn't sure what you'd learnt.

question: I have learnt, kid. I've learnt to read.
answer: I'll pick you up next week, OK?

question: That sounds a good plan.
answer: Good. Quietly, or shall we make a big fuss?

question: Quietly.
answer: OK. Quietly.

question: Take care, kid.
answer: You too. See you next week. She didn't pack. She never intended to leave.

question: Ms Mather?
answer: Yes. You're Michael Berg. I was expecting you. So you must tell me

question: I was already here. I was at a conference in Boston.
answer: You're a lawyer?

question: Yes.
answer: I was intrigued by your letter but I can't say I wholly understood it. You attended the trial?

question: Yes. Almost twenty years ago. I was a law student. I remember you, I remember your mother very clearly.
answer: My mother died in Israel - a good many years ago.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Go on, please.

question: Perhaps you heard. Hanna Schmitz recently died. She killed herself.
answer: She was a friend of yours?

question: A kind of friend. It's as simple as this. Hanna was illiterate for the greater part of her life.
answer: Is that an explanation of her behaviour?

question: No.
answer: Or an excuse?

question: No. No. She taught herself to read when she was in prison. I sent her tapes. She'd always liked being read to.
answer: Why don't you start by being honest with me? At least start that way. What was the nature of your friendship?

question: When I was young I had an affair with Hanna.
answer: I'm not sure I can help you, Mr. Berg. Or rather, even if I could I'm not willing to.

question: I was almost sixteen when I took up with her. The affair only lasted a summer. But.
answer: But what? I see. And did Hanna Schmitz acknowledge the effect she'd had on your life?

question: She'd done much worse to other people. I've never told anyone.
answer: People ask all the time what I learned in the camps. But the camps weren't therapy. What do you think these places were? Universities? We didn't go there to learn. One becomes very clear about these things. What are you asking for? Forgiveness for her? Or do you just want to feel better yourself? My advice, go to the theatre, if you want catharsis. Please. Go to literature. Don't go to the camps. Nothing comes out of the camps. Nothing.

question: What she wanted...what she wanted was to leave you her money. I have with me.
answer: To do what?

question: As you think fit. Here.
answer: When I was a little girl, I had a tea-tin for my treasures. Not quite like this. It had Cyrillic lettering. I took it with me to the camp, but it got stolen.

question: What was in it?
answer: Oh. Sentimental things. A piece of hair from our dog. Some tickets to operas my father had taken me to. It wasn't stolen for its contents. It was the tin itself which was valuable, what you could do with it. There's nothing I can do with this money. If I give it to anything associated with the extermination of the Jews, then to me it will seem like absolution and that is something I'm neither willing nor in a position to grant.

question: I was thinking maybe an organization to encourage literacy.
answer: Good. Good.

question: Do you know if there's a Jewish organization?
answer: I'll be surprised if there isn't. There's a Jewish organisation for everything. Not that illiteracy is a very Jewish problem. Why don't you find out? Send them the money.

question: Shall I do it in Hanna's name?
answer: As you think fit. I'll keep the tin.
